ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Linear Algebra, some basic analysis, familiarity with proofs, and general mathematical intuition
Gained experience with higher-level problem solving that what I typically encountered in other courses. Pushed me to be more creative when thinking about math.

Learned a lot about building upon the knowledge from MATH 230 into more linear algebra focused topics in the first half of the course, and later switched back to analysis and integration starting from some fundamental definitions, really learning math from a different way than taught in typical high school settings where formulas are just handed to you without going in depth into the definitions and proving all of the properties (e.g. for determinants and the sort).
I gained so much mathematical insight and I learned how to do proofs.
Linear algebra, so things like dimension, rank-nullity, change of basis, row reduction, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, as well as integrals
Introductory linear algebra and calculus with proof

I developed an in depth understanding of the fundamentals of linear algebra, calculus, and a whole bunch of other stuff! Not only did I learn the broad concepts behind each of the subjects covered, I also learned how to prove them!

The skills that I developed the most during this course were my rational thinking, my "internal mathematical feeling" (being able to intuitively understand what a problem or a statement means and how to prove it), and my writing! When I started the course sequence (back in 230), I had very little clue what I was doing and I struggled to keep up a bit. But now, my understanding of the math is so complete that I can blast through problem sets!

The course explored introductory linear algebra, tangentially touched on integrals, and cursorily mentioned a bunch of other miscellaneous topics. The main takeaway though is easily the ability to think creatively and write succint and coherent proofs from scratch.

An assortment of important theorems and concepts in linear algebra including Schur decomposition, Invertible Matrix Theorem, Spectral Theorem, eigenvalues, diagonalizability, etc. Wrapping up with multivariable calculus concepts culminating in Implicit Function Theorem.
I learned about linear algebra and proof techniques. It helped build a foundation for future math courses.

I gained a lot of new knowledge in many important topics regarding linear algebra and multivariable calculus. The course was well designed and led to many insights about how interrelated different aspects of these fields are.
Experience writing in LaTeX. Experience collaborating with other students to complete long and difficult assignments that required a significant lack of sleep.
Proof-writing, multivariable calculus, linear algebra, other random math stuff (number theory, manifolds, modulus, etc)
Proof writing
I developed skills in linear algebra.

Linear algebra, formalized integration, implicit and inverse function theorems, general vector analysis on manifolds

but not generalized stokes :(
This class helped me to develop my proof-writing skills and taught me topics in linear algebra and calculus, going from linear algebra in the beginning and finishing with calculus.
A continuation of MATH 230. Mathematical proofs; linear algebra and introduction to analysis.

theory of linear algebra
connections between multivariable calculus and linear algebra
Proof-based linear algebra and multivariable calculus, which is mostly integrals this semester.
Continuation of practice in writing proofs with an emphasis on linear algebra, integrals, and manifolds (inverse function theorem, implicit function theorem)
Linear algebra and analysis, finishes 230 and teaches the subjects in relation to one another
I learned how to collaborate with others efficiently.
Continuation of 230, lots of linear algebra and some analysis.

This course was my introdcution to proof-based math. I learned how to work with axiomaticc mathematics. I developed a strong foundation for many of the same concepts I encourtered in high school, and I gained deeper insights on many of theses topics. These include calculus on manifolds and a rigorous introduction to vector spaces and linear operators.
Proof based math!

MATH 231 is part of a two course sequence along with MATH 230. Through the two courses, I developed an in-depth understanding behind vector calculus and linear algebra. I built strong proof-writing skills and engaged in new approaches to the math topics contained in vector calculus and linear algebra.
This class, as with 230, greatly enhanced my proof-writing skills. Additionally, it helped base much of my mathematical knowledge on rigorous rather than intuitive grounds.
Greater grasp of proofs, better understanding of some multivariable calculus techniques.
We learned about linear algebra and manifolds and the stuff on the syllabus. As importantly we got a sense of how math works and how things can be defined and proven within a framework.

The ability to grasp and struggle with concepts that were unfamiliar with me; the ability to balance a heavy workload as a first year; the ability to form connections with others and work together on problems (collaboration was encouraged). I was able to learn quite a bit of mathematics from analysis, linear algebra, topology, calculus--there was a lot of math in this class.

Just like 230 before it, the most important skill taught in 231 is proof-writing and logic. I hope that after all the work from this year my proofs have gotten a lot more watertight (but I guess that's for others to judge, not me lol). Content-wise, we spent most of the time doing linear algebra, and also a bit more real analysis (multivariate for the most part) that we didn't cover in 230. I found proof-based linear algebra to be very computational at times so it helped me get better at that too.
Linear algebra concepts in a proof based format and multi variable calculus concepts
Proof writing, deeper mathematical thinking
I developed a good insight into proof based math.
Proof-writing skills, linear algebra, basic analysis, problem-solving skills.
I learned how to prove lots of things using theorems in many different fields of mathematics.
Continuation of Math 230: rank, determinant, eigenvalue, inner product, integral, etc.
Proof writing skills, an understanding of linear algebra and basic parts of other fields of math and how they connect
Proof-writing skills and the ability to evaluate the robustness of a line of argument.

I learned a lot about linear algebra, and a bit more about vector calculus and its relationship with linear algebra. However, the most important skill I learned (continued from MATH 230) was how to go about solving a problem and figuring out a proof. That openness and uncertainty absolutely terrified me at the beginning of the year, but I've come to kind of relish it. I learned, basically, to wallow in the uncertainty of a problem, and to be okay with that uncertainty.
rigorous proof-writing abilities, critical quantitative reasoning skills
A deepened knowledge of linear algebra and analysis.

Thorough introduction to linear algebra, matrix properties and operations; multivariable integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Inverse and Implicit Function Theorems; topics in topology and real analysis. More generally, a lot of experience in mathematical thought, proof writing, synthesizing knowledge from different topics to solve problems, appreciating cool areas of math!
Math! So much math! Also, how to think logically and prove things, which is great.

Learned about linear algebra including vector spaces, basis/dimension, eigenvalues/eigenvectors. Tied these topics into analysis stuff from 230 last semester. Learned about multidimensional integration.
A more foundational, proof based understanding of Linear Algebra, Vector Calculus, and a bit of Real Analysis.
vector calculus, linear algebra
proofs, linear algebra, analysis
I developed and improved my proof techniques and learned a lot more about linear algebra and multidimensional theorems and concepts
How to write proofs, how to translate math to pictures/graphs

I learned linear algebra extremely well but most importantly I learned how to think like a mathematician and problem solver even in the face of material that I didn't understand the first time. This course teaches you how to struggle and work for understanding of a question and not get phased but truly hard work.
Practice with proof writing, intuition in linear algebra in n dimensions, a more rigorous definition of integration.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course builds upon a lot of the content from 230 and provides a strong solid mathematical foundation in linear algebra, analysis, and proof-writing. This course could be improved with more timely feedback on graded work.

This course is very Pset intensive, which makes the learning repetitive at times. However, while this is a criticism, I can't think of many other ways with which this sort of teaching is possible. The course requires much practice on the part of the student, so a high workload is logical.

Pat is a great lecturer, although I think I liked his teaching in 230 better. This semester some things felt a little more hand-wavy/'you do this and then obviously get that'. Also, the speed of grading was terrible... everything was graded around two months after it was originally due. OH were usually helpful and gathertown was a pretty good way to do it/preserve the spirit of small group collaboration of normal/in-person OH. I thought this class was slightly harder/less intuitive than 230.

Great lectures, great instructor, but towards the end the proofs of complex ideas related to the Implicit and Inverse Function Theorem were breezed over and were very hard to understand. Felt like I wasn't sure exactly what was going on and kind of applied the theorems without a full grasp of what was going on. Other than that small issue, the first 9/10ths of the course were amazing.
I think the homework was very difficult, but the teaching was excellent and Pat is an incredible instructor.

Well, this class isn't being taught next year, but... Strenghts: Pat is extremely kind and makes math fun. Also, I feel as though Pat is better at teaching linear algebra than analysis, so the "bonus material" was better suited to the class // Weaknesses: Can feel a little disorganized. I don't really know why we did integrals so late.

Strength: I think we have covered a decent amount of material and shown the connections between calculus and lin-alg
Weakness: sometimes the organization feels a bit chaotic, and we do not get in-depth on any of the topics

Strengths: The lectures are straightforward, and build upon the lectures we previously looked at, so you are always moving forward. All lectures are recorded, so you can revise information later if you did not fully understand the material in one class. The problem sets are challenging and push your mathematical thinking (as they should),  but there are plenty of office hour sessions for the students to make use of if you need support. The whole environment of the class is really positive, because the teacher is always upbeat and encouraging to the students (not to mention is flexible in his due dates if you have conflicting deadlines or something important came up/happened). The TA's are really nice and helpful too. On top of this, I found that the student body of the class was really nice and a lot of fun, and we helped each other better understand the material. Overall, it was an amazing course.

I cannot think of a weakness for this course. (Only one preference: the lecture notes are usually in a file format that is really small when you download it. If it is possible to make it bigger that would be great!)

Strengths: 1. Pat is a gem of a person - he's helpful, accomodating and just generally a great guy. His lectures are always engaging because of his enthusiasm and his laidback style of teaching (which often features cameos of his three cats). 2. Many might deem this one a weakness, but the problem sets really cemented concepts taught in class, while honing the all-important proof-writing skillset. 3. The grading is pretty generous, and if you're working on problem sets with others, getting an A is not hard at all. Weaknesses: 1. This sequence is called Vector Calculus & Linear Algebra, but content is majorly lacking on the vector calculus side of things - we didn't get to any of the vector calculus theorems, which is unexcusable given the title of the course. 2. It's a lot of work every week, but imo it's worth it.

Strengths: Pat's enthusiasm and great explanations as always, problem sets were reasonable yet challenging enough for me to synthesize the material, and the material itself was interesting. Weaknesses: some theorems in class were proved somewhat less rigorously, and some lectures felt rushed because there were a lot of topics to cover.
A strength of the course was the wide range of interesting and difficult problems on the problem sets each week which helped me to solidify my understanding of the material we covered in class.

Teaching staff was enthusiastic and supportive. I liked Ed Discussion for asking questions and getting answers in a pretty timely manner, but I would've liked it more if posts were anonymous to instructors, not just other students. I often felt paranoid about the optics of showing that I didn't understand a certain topic or question and some anonymity would have helped that.

Strengths: Pat's lectures are mostly pretty good, the TA's office hours are a life-saver. Weaknesses: the problem sets are almost unnecessarily long, sometimes the explanations on problems are not very clear and I would finish the problem not knowing what I had proved and how it connects to other stuff we're doing (you'll eventually find out that it does connect when Pat mentions it a few months later--but at that point it's not very useful). The class is overall a bit unorganized.

The biggest strength is pat. Also homework assignmentsthese were always challenging and at least as educational (in terms of learning new theorems and proof techniques) as lectures. I cant think of any weaknesses.

Strengths: the topic is very interesting and learning about proof based math has been extremely helpful for me even though I dont plan on majoring in STEM. Pat is great in explaining difficult concepts and he genuinely cares about his students. Weaknesses: assignments and exams can be graded and returned faster. It can also be helpful to have a detailed syllabus listing topics, assignments/exams dates, etc.

Strengths:
- challenging problem sets
- good presentation of info in lecture

Potential improvements:
- motivate proofs in lecture with important examples
- have supplemental office hours for specific topics
- ordering of topics could be more smooth I think

It is a challenging but fun course, the Psets are pretty challenging but it should be fine if you attend office hours for help, which are available in multiple time periods across the week. We did not use a textbook this semester, so it may feel less organized if you are used to having a textbook, but the lectures are pretty well laid out and I didn't think it was a problem.

The level at which content is presented is a clear advantage of the course. You simply learn so much! The focus on proof writing is excellent for an introductory course to the math major, picking up some cool math along the way. There is a good mixture of proofs and examples provided (although I would like to see some of these proofs in more detail; the supplemental videos were helpful here). Pat is super caring, helpful, and a little chaotic; the class is less structured as a result (I personally like to have some reference text but the flexibility of the class did allow us to see many cool topics). There is a lot of work! It is quite the time commitment. Do not underestimate how long it takes to write out PSETs!! Collaboration and friendship are key to get through the year.

Grading feedback could be substantially improved. The quality of the feedback I received was very helpful, but it was significantly delayed.
Great course! Only frustration is that it takes a long time to get grades back, so you have to complete assignments without having received feedback on your previous assignments.

Strength - the encouragement of collaboration, course materials, organization 
Weakness - I didn't really find any weakness.

The course was very well organized, with lots of office hours and extracurricular opportunities to enhance your understanding. I think one thing that could be improved would be a "checkup" every so often about proof writing style, since I felt like we didn't talk about this much after the beginning of the course, but it would have been good to work on being more succinct (in a way that's still clear).

This course had many strengths. The community had the most inclusive culture I have encountered in a STEM environment. The material was fascinating and engaging. I believe this course could be improved by centralizing the material into an easier-to-review format in addition to the available lecture notes. Since this course built upon previous theories that we had proven in class to address increasingly difficult mathematical concepts, there were specific theorems that we were allowed to use on exams and in problem sets. I think it would be helpful to have a list of the theorems that were proven in class, because I often found myself combing through the lecture notes to find the theorem statement.

Strengths - the professor was great, lots of office hours for help
Weaknesses - the problem sets were very long

The course contained a lot of information. Most classes were spent reviewing multiple proofs and/or examples that challenged  students to think deeply about the topic at hand. However, the subject material felt all over at times, jumping from one topic to another. The homework, while relating to the material covered in class, often asked students to learn concepts on their own.
Overall, this is a very strong class. I think it could benefit from a slightly faster pace at times. Otherwise, I dont have any other suggestions.
Doesn't quite teach multivariable calculus. If I hadn't already had experience with calc 3, this course wouldn't give me the knowledge to apply and solve problems.

Strengths are amazing professor who makes things make feel intuitive and covers what feels like are just the right things.
Only notable weakness is slow grading, but grading is also nice so its not a big worry.

Pat is a great teacher; everyone loves him and it's so easy to get to know him -- there are LOTS of office hours, GO! Pat makes the class very welcoming and encourages students to collaborate, and he being the professor of MATH 231 (the second portion of the sequence) was a great part of why I continued. A weakness would be getting feedback for your work--like homeworks and portions of tests, however, justing knowing Pat and the other AWESOME TAs, they would be more than willing to talk to you about it. Also, if you go to office hours, you already know if you are on the right track or not.

Strengths: Pat is a legend, huge support system, content is interesting and classes were a joy to attend :)

Weaknesses: Can't really think of much besides the workload feeling higher than necessary, but that's MATH 231 and everyone knows what they're getting in to.
Very good broad overview of mathematical material, and how mathematical material should be interacted with and functions. Introduction to proof based writing.
Problems sets were not graded fast enough so I didnt feel I was getting feedback quickly. Other than that, no complaints because Pat was an amazing instructor all year.
Fosters a lot of community within the class, makes sure everyone understands and is always open for questions
The class is well structured for beginner mathematicians. This class really teaches you how to write proofs.

Strengths: Material is fairly interesting and not too difficult, professor is awesome. Weaknesses: homework can have a tendency to feel like busywork/tedious. There were a lot of students who took this course in my year, so a weakness was also that the problem sets were not returned very quickly, which it difficult to measure my own progress in the course.

I didn't think this course had any weaknesses. It is very tough, but it is also incredibly satisfying. Working in this course gave me a great sense of accomplishment. Oh, actually, there was one weakness. Our work didn't get graded for a long, long time. If we could get more graders that would be great.

This course provides a very solid basis in multivariable calculus and linear algebra. The proofs did in class and homework greatly facilitate the understanding of new concepts. The course materials are illustrated well by Pat.

Pat is incredible, and refining our proof writing skills is really important in helping us improve the quality of our work. Two small weaknesses were (1) there aren't many applications/we don't get too much of a chance to do "plug and chug" problems which may be helpful to practice for "real life" (by the nature of the proof-based course) and (2) the ending of the course felt a bit rushed, and I personally don't feel like we really got full closure on the topic of manifolds. Literally everything else about this class is amazing--the community, the quality of the course material, Pat's emerald hair, etc.

The weekly problem sets, while pretty draining and occasionally stressful, create a necessary rhythm and keep the intensity of the course pretty constant. Pat is an engaging, human, fun, smart lecturer. The one complaint would be the grading of assignments, which often came late, unpredictably, or not at all.
Strengths: great sense of community, extensive opportunities for office hours and extra support, approachability of professor

This course had a huge task set for it: math 230-231 is supposed to be all about community, on top of introducing people unfamiliar with formal mathematics to it, all over a zoom lecture, with no meaningful breaks. I think that the class was a good class, but it was fighting an uphill battle, especially as everyone got tired, both the students and the instructors. I have immense respect for Pat's ability to run an engaging class, and I think when classes resume in person most of these problems will be solved.

Course organization is great, content builds on itself in a very logical way. Course format, in terms of how lectures relate to problem sets as well as the large availability of TAs and peer tutors, works great! Content is also very interesting, covering the basics of multivariable calculus and linear algebra sufficiently for mathematics and the natural sciences, as well as introducing students enthusiastic about pure math to interesting areas to explore further.
Strengths: Awesome instructor & great course. Please dont get rid of it! Weaknesses: Grading was slow
great professor, grading should have been faster
the course content of the class doesnt directly relate to the problem sets
I felt like the course was done quite well, the only thing I would've enjoyed more was if we got more prompt and quick feedback for our psets
The problem sets were sometimes too long, but very helpful in learning the material better.

A strength was the heavy workload because it forced us to practice the content we learned in class consistently. The professor was also amazing and made the class a lot more interesting. A weakness would be the lack of feedback, as a lot of the assignments were graded very late.

Weakness - this course doesn't exist anymore.  Strength - Pat Devlin!! Pat is the best teacher at Yale. He is kind, supportive even beyond class, and super smart yet approachable. He is amazingly clear and really by the end of the course he feels more like a friend than anything else.

Strengths: Consistent, and although the workload is pretty heavy for every pset, you know what you're getting. Even if it took a long time, it's clear what the work required is in order to do well, and it's doable. You have several directions to ask for help from the many people that are willingpeers, pset groups, the office hours, online!

Weaknesses: Even though I learned a lot from 230, I still was often not prepared for the amount of time I needed to spend to finish and type up some assignments. Unless you're already pretty good at proof-based math, be prepared to spend at least the time required in 230, if not more for longer psets. Feedback on psets and midterms was sometimes delayed, which definitely could have helped me catch a mistake that I later repeated on the final...
The course was very well-organized and overall a great experience! I can't think of any major weaknesses (and I know this course won't be offered in the future anymore)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was excellently adapted to the COVID situation with the mixture of online lectures and a plethora of office hours.

Well taught online lectures at a perfect pace using an extended whiteboard so students could still see previous notes if the instructor moved on (avoiding the problem of switching to a new slide too fast)

I think the sense of community building succeeded even in the pandemic. I have many friends that are in MATH 231 with me and they are awesome. I think having office hours not on Zoom but on a different software called Gathertown also made it better.
Pat is great with the iPad!
I like watching recorded lectures because of my time zone. It works well.

I felt like the whole set up for the class was geared toward COVID-19 learning. All the problem sets were done independently anyway, and the teacher always made each online lecture helpful and meaningful. Not to mention, all materials from class (and from outside the class that the teacher thought would be helpful) were provided at all times. There were lots of office hour sessions too. On top of this, in the era of COVID-19 learning, deadlines did become more shaky for everything (and in some other classes apparently, the workload increased). The professor took this into consideration by having a reasonably flexible deadline schedule for all assignments that allowed the students to submit their assignments at times that did not put them behind in other classes.
Virtual course notes worked well and everything ran smoothly.
This course worked well in a virtual format. Pat was able to make the lectures enjoyable and engaging despite them being online this semester.
There is a threshold limiting how high "virtual engagement" can be, and I think this class just about reached that.
The course meeting times were inconveniently placed during lunchtime, so was not able to attend live lectures.

The Gather Town office hours were really nice, since we could collaborate in different groups depending on where we are in the Psets. All lecture notes and recordings are uploaded, so it is pretty easy to review classes or catch up to a class you missed.

Having access to video recordings of class and screen captures of lecture notes was super useful! I also found that the online office hours via Gathertown were convenient and helped me find friends to work on PSETs together. The friendships I made here go beyond the class. Breakout rooms during class for discussions increased immersion although they sometimes ran quiet (keeping the same group over each day was better for this purpose).

Recorded lectures and course notes were super helpful. I was able to come back to them anytime I was confused with the pset. 
We were also able to collaborate with friends on zoom, which was nice. 

However, I wish that we were able to take classes in person just so that we learn about each other a little more.
Gathertown for office hours worked very well, and even better than Zoom office hours.

The office hours held using gather.town and an online whiteboard were very sucessful. The YUMS speakers and Pat's weekly 'Pat's cats' power hour' were also very engaging, and an important part of the creation of the rich undergraduate math culture at Yale. Of all of my classes, this one was the most successful in the transition to the online format.
The office hours were great!
I think Gather Town was a very creative way of doing office hours. Overall, the main problem was finding a group to do psets with as an off-campus student.
Pat's live lectures were great, he handled the transition well.

There was quite a bit of engagement in the class; Pat does a warm-up in every lecture and will frequently ask students to answer the problems. He also broke us out into breakout rooms; I personally didn't like that part as much, but I'm sure many others liked it. 

For office hours, we just gather.town and that was GREAT--I love the platform, it's super engaging and fitting for those us working in groups without going through the hassle of Zoom breakout rooms (not to mention aesthetics)!

Pat's live handwritten lectures were great for the Zoom setting because it takes more time to convey information when there's such a disconnect between us and him. He frequently asked in polls how well we were understanding the material and adjusted accordingly, which was also extremely helpful. The office hours website (gather.town) I found to be a bit glitchy at times - there were certainly ways that made it better than Zoom rooms but I guess I just never acclimated to it so it always felt weird for me.

The live virtual lectures as well as the recorded lectures we could watch on our own time if we couldn't make it or if we needed to go back and understand something better, using gathertown as a space for office hours
I was never a fan of the office hours on Gather. Zoom was better for me, personally.
The lecture format - live lectures that were recorded - worked well, as it allowed for in-person discussion while also accommodating for those who could not attend live.

The online classes were really well done. Pat made great use of his tablet, writing as if he were using a whiteboard. I've found that seeing the material being written is much more engaging than pre-written notes. There were also virtual office hours, which were very fun.
The permission for async attendance suits students in other time zones well. The breakout sessions during class also facilitate discussion among students.
Having the gather.town available was wonderful - it really let students collaborate. Breakout rooms could've been utilized more in lecture, but overall virtual engagement was successful.

I think that the online format worked well in supporting everything that should've been happening in the course. One drawback is that I didn't feel like I was able to engage with the community and find solid study/PSET groups, but that's mostly because I took the class asynchronously. Hopefully we'll return to in-person things soon and the online format of things will subside.

Pat's method of taking notes during class and then posting those notes to Canvas for later reference is probably the best I've encountered in any class. The use of breakout rooms was also really effective. No complaints here!
Office hours via GatherTown was phenomenal
I think the class could use more breakout rooms / meetings outside of class.

Ability for students to discuss lecture content in breakout rooms was very helpful for internalizing content; long office hours on gather.town were immensely helpful to allow students to collaborate and receive help.
Gathertown office hours are the bomb. Please keep doing this.
recorded lectures were very helpful
it was much harder to understand the content through an online lecture, but being able to reference recorded lectures was very helpful
Office hours was super helpful, as well as recorded lectures. An improvement would be shifting away from the gather town platform and back to zoom.

The open office hour format on gathertown was pretty cool for chilling with classmates and working through problems together, though Zoom was also useful if I was looking to work solo and unmute to ask a question to the TA.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely! 231 is a great continuation of 230. Personally, I found the class to be a little easier than 230 in content and workload. If you took 230, I'd highly recommend continuing the course track and finishing up with 231.

If you are willing to spend the time to master the content, this is a great course! It may be a bit superfluous for non-math-related majors, however, so be aware of the time commitment and your personal workload comfort level.

Personally, the content of 230/231 helped me figure out that I'm not a fan of analysis at all (and I'm probably not going to take any more analysis courses in the future.. though we'll see). However, 230/231 did really help me improve my rigorous proof-writing skills, and I enjoyed having Pat as a teacher. I guess I would say take this course if you want to have a (kind of intense) introduction to college math, analysis, and proofs, but I would note that I thought (and I think others thought too) that 231 was harder than 230. Also definitely work on the psets with people and ask for help at OH if you don't understand things
Absolutely, any course with Pat is a course to enjoy. He teaches math in a wonderful way so you feel comfortable as you're introduced to new topics.
I would recommend this course to a student interested in pursuing a math major or who wants to explore proofs, but not just to anyone.

Math 230-231 is being replaced by 225/226 and 255/256, so I will offer my thoughts on those classes. I want to applaud the math department for making the switch. It was completely necessary. I can't believe Yale didn't really offer a concrete real analysis class before. Furthermore, in my opinion, the blending of real analysis, linear algebra, and bonus material from Pat was a little ridiculous. I understand that people enjoyed the bonus material, but I was here to learn analysis and linear algebra, not learn about modulo arithmetic and other things. It was annoying when I was challenged by bonus material, not analysis or linear algebra. Also, separating the subjects and introducing levels will make things much better. I came in with a fair amount of analysis and linear algebra already, but I wanted a rigorous summary of everything again. Instead, for me, class felt not completely rigorous and problem sets were challenging because of the bonus material, not the actual analysis and linear algebra content, which could be infuriating. It kind of felt like the class was hard just for the sake of being hard, which could be fixed by simply providing actual analysis and linear algebra problems on the pset. In this vein, I hope the new classes can teach more related material rather than the bonus stuff, such as least squares in linear algebra, and compactness, series, uniform continuity, and uniform convergence of functions and stuff in analysis. I have high hopes for the new sequence, especially since Professor Minsky will be teaching 256. He is an incredible lecturer, blending the perfect amount of rigorous proofs and intuition along the way. His greatest strength is writing problems that seem impossible, but with sufficient thought are conquerable. The only thing is, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, DO NOT USE BEALS. USE A  DIFFERENT TEXTBOOK. USE RUDIN. Beals is structured weird and contains so many errors. Rudin is the most rigorous you can find (since 256 is for people who know proofs already, the rigor won't be an issue), and its problems are all gold.
Yes, but the department has decided to change its structure anyway, and I think it's a good decision.

YES! If you want to be a mathematician, this class is fantastic! Not only do you cover everything you need to, it is a lot of fun and the material you cover is very interesting.

Even if you are not planning on being a mathematician, I recommend this class anyway! I am not planning on being a mathematician myself, but I took the class for the intellectual challenge, and found that I really enjoyed it. I personally found that the problem sets were like sets of puzzles or riddles that clever and clear thinking could overcome (there were some very beautiful problems we did that had beautiful solutions too). Not to mention the professor is really nice :) .

Overall, I recommend this class to everybody. (If the level of the material is too great for you, that is fine. I recommend just trying it a bit anyway in the shopping period because it is fun!)

I would highly recommend this course to another student, it gives a strong background in proof writing methods, as well as covering the material (vector calc and linear algebra) to an interesting level of depth (even for those who have taken similar courses in the past).

If you're a potential math major looking to bolster your proof-writing abilities and learn linear algebra while you're at it, take this course. But if you're a science major seeking a more fundamental understanding of the tools of vector calculus and linear algebra, you should probably look elsewhere, because some important vector calculus theorems, and importantly, a lot of practice that's required to implement the concepts taught in class, are gravely missing in this course.

This course is being discontinued, so if you're reading this, you want to know about Pat. He's excellent. He's a fantastic teacher, he loves his students, and he does a great job of creating a community through his classroom (even virtually!). If you get the chance to take a class with Pat, DO IT.

Well this course is disappearing from future semesters anyways. Linear algebra and multivariable calculus is important and learning it from a proof-based perspective is interesting and helpful, although you may have to self-study some multivariable calculus concepts outside of class like Stokes or Green's Theorem.
Yes. I would recommend this course to any student interested in taking math in college.

I would recommend this course to another student. The course exposes students to many different interesting topics and it could be useful for people from a wide variety of math backgrounds, ranging from people that haven't seen proofs before to ones that are already familiar with them.
Only if you intend to major in math. I think it is too much of a time and energy commitment without enough application to other topics to justify taking this sequence and majoring in something else.

I have mixed feelings about 230/1. The material is definitely interesting if you're looking for an intellectual challenge, but the unnecessarily high workload actually made me engage less with the material and more focused on finishing the problem sets. We probably proved a lot of interesting stuff, but there's no time to think about what we proved with deadlines every week. Pat's lectures are pretty helpful, but he moves really fast--I often feel ashamed that I don't get the stuff that he says is obvious. Pat's a great teacher, but the format of the course is really limiting. I suppose none of this really matters though since this will be the last year of 230/1.
Yes

If and only if the student is a math major, yes. For math majors, this is THE class to take your first year. Youre connected with the passionate and welcoming community that is Yale math, and you see all the important stuff you need to know to appreciate college math.

MATH 230/231 will no longer be offered next year, but I strongly recommend students to take a class with Pat! Proof based math with Pat has changed my way of thinking and opened up my world, even though I didnt come to Yale think Im necessarily good at math.

Yes 
- good for learning multivariable/linear algebra rigorously
- acquaints with proof-based math
- valuable experience even after having taken multivariable/linear algebra before college

If you want to learn about proof-based mathematics or are planning to major in math, I would highly recommend this course, although it will not be available next year. It is a nice introduction to proof-based mathematics, and if you took MATH 230, it is a pretty smooth transition since the professor is the same.

Yes, but with the understanding that the PSETs dominate your week (not a problem when you are with math friends :)). This math sequence is highly demanding but also rewarding. I began with no formal training in proof-based math and have left confident in my ability to write detailed, thorough arguments. Although it can be intense, this class delves into the details and shows what is at the heart of mathematics. The community I have found at TA office hours was invaluable. I met some truly awesome people and I am looking forward to where our friendship will go!
Yes! Although it's kind of a moot point since it won't be offered in the future. If you enjoy math and proofs I would definitely recommend this sequence, or whichever course they have to replace it.
YES! Although this course wouldn't be offered any longer :(

Absolutely! If you haven't seen proofs before, you will learn an entirely new way of thinking about math. You will also meet other amazing students, and working on psets together is a great experience.
Since this course is not being offered next year, I would hesitate to recommend it to another student.
Yes! if you are interested in proofs!
Yes. Its a great class if youve got the math chops for it.
Certainly, it was a great time.

Strongly, even if not a math major, IF you have time. It is an awesome intro to understanding what math means in a way that you will never have from the other intro calc sequences. And Pat is the best. However the time required isnt trivial; although deadline flexibility makes it a bit easier to fit around.

We're the last cohort of MATH 230/231 students, so none of you reading this will be able to take it. However, Pat is teaching MATH 225 (linear algebra) Fall 2021 and you should definitely take that course. I personally really liked linear algebra, and I think the workload would be much more manageable than MATH 230/231. 


Not to mention, Pat is a great person (all the AWESOME TAs as well); get to know them -- there are LOTS of office hours, *GO*! Pat makes the class very welcoming and encourages students to collaborate, and he being the professor of MATH 231 (the second portion of the sequence) was a great part of why I continued (in addition to the friends I made). If you like very clear feedback for your work, a weakness would be that. Homeworks and portions of tests may not be handed back,  however, justing knowing Pat and the other AWESOME TAs, they would be more than willing to talk to you about it. Also, if you've done the homeworks, you already know the material, so it's not like you're missing out on knowledge. Linear Algebra is fun, do it!

Yes, 100% recommend! Before I talk about the class in particular I think it's important to point out that 231 won't be offered again (they're restructuring the intro classes) so here's my rambling attempt at explaining the changes to anyone curious: the old intensive classes (230 and 231) which each combined proof-based vector calculus (aka real analysis) and linear algebra are being split into linear algebra only (226) and real analysis only (256). Since the real analysis class is covering a stuff in a different order, 250 and 300/301 are being phased out in favor of 255/256 (single-variable analysis, 256 intensive version of 255) and 302 (multivariable analysis, manifolds and stuff) that is no longer a prerequisite for 305 (the way 301 was). Due to COVID (and perhaps also the impending change) our 230 in the fall was almost entirely analysis and 231 almost entirely linear algebra, so 230 from fall 2020 was basically a dry run for 256 and 231 this term was a dry run for 226. I hope this helps people compare course reviews while the transition is taking place. But anyway on to the class itself, Pat is AMAZING (deservedly given a teaching award this year!) and really supports everyone in the class. Linear algebra was fun, probably not my favorite course of the semester content-wise, but definitely the most fun class to go to because of how accessible and interesting Pat made the lectures. You know what you're getting into with the psets having done 230, lots of intellectually challenging proofs - the difference is with linear algebra it's more computational than theoretical (as it is with analysis) which I personally found to be more enjoyable. The workload is more or less the same as it is in 230, some people say higher and others (a majority I think) say a bit lower. But definitely use the opportunity Pat offers to really get to know your classmates, because the 231 community was really fantastic and supportive. Again you probably know all this stuff coming from 230 (or now 226 going into 256 or whatever), but it's a lot of work, intellectually challenging, but the experience is great and it's very possible to do well if you put in the time.
Since this course is not going to be offered anymore, I will instead say that any course that Pat teaches is worth taking.

YES!!!! Even though this is the last year of this class :( If you have the chance to take a class with Pat then please do it!! You seriously won't regret it. It is a lot of work but I have made some of my closest friends at Yale through this class by working on weekly PSETs together. All of the ULAs are amazing (especially Matt King!) and they will help you get through the course if you go to office hours consistently.
Yes, but this class is a LOT of work. Assuming you dont already know proofs and linear algebra, only take this class if you are willing for this class to be one of your most time consuming classes.

Yes, especially with Pat Devlin. The material is fairly cool and interesting, and Pat makes this class awesome, even if you don't really care about the class. (Ok, so I guess I'm recommending taking a class with Pat.)

I would. This course is not only very interesting from a learning perspective, but it fosters a great community. The emphasis on group work let me make friends, which was especially important because of COVID.

(Sadly this class will be canceled) Yet definitely if it is offered sometime later. This class suits best students interested in seeing proof-based math. The extensive appearance of proofs helps build one's proving skills and solid knowledge in vector calculus and linear algebra.

Yes! It was lovely to get to connect to a community of peers in math and the professor was amazing. It had a significant workload though, which was fine during the pandemic, but make sure you're ready to commit that much time to the class.

100%, but it is quite rigorous and thorough, so students should be prepared for that. Pat is a gem, and the course is very well-designed. It will be proof-based, which many students aren't necessarily used to, but the course is really dedicated to helping students learn to write proofs and think like mathematicians. Even though this class isn't being offered next semester, I would definitely recommend friends to take a class with Pat, as he really helped invigorate my interest in math through the 230/231 sequence.

I've read some student reviews on Coursetable suggesting that this course is only worth taking if you plan to major in math or if you're deeply interested in pure math. I'm a humanities kid at heart, and I don't plan to major in math. But I like solving problems, and I like the process of figuring out a logical way to get from point A to point B. If that sounds like you -- in other words, if you enjoy math in any capacity and think you're okay at it -- I don't think there's any reason for you not to take the class, with the possible exception of the workload.
Strongly recommend; in spite of the challenge, Pat makes this course incredibly rewarding through the myriad of extra support opportunities.
Yes absolutely! This is a wonderful introduction to the math major at Yale, both academically and socially.

I would recommend this course to any student considering studies in pure or applied mathematics or anyone that enjoys mathematical problem solving and wants accelerated completion of introductory real analysis, multivariable calculus and linear algebra.
Yes! Learning how to prove things is awesome, and the course was an unbelievable amount of fun! Ill recommend this course to everyone as long as Im alive.
I would absolutely recommend 230/231 (it's sad that it won't be offered in this form next year). It's so satisfying to learn things in a proof-based context.
good course but can be a lot of work sometimes
definitely a challenge
I would most definitely recommend this course, as you will end up learning a lot of information at a very digestible pace, and there's a lot of leeway for if you're confused and need to catch up
Yes, I feel like I understand multi variable calculus and linear algebra a lot better.

Yes! Professor Devlin was amazing and made the class so interesting. There are a ton of opportunities to meet other students and to learn about math. The workload is quite challenging so be sure not to pad your schedule with other heavy workload classes.
Yes! Ha sike you can't take it anymore!

Yes! Even with the huge workload and time needed, sometimes spent just staring at a problem or getting stuck on a misunderstood definition for hours, in the end, the class and the assignments were very fulfilling for me. I think an in-person class would amplify these best parts and also decrease the pressure I sometimes felt when I thought I was the only one struggling to finish problems when others really felt the same. If you're looking to get some hard but fair work and to gain more appreciation for math, take the class!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Lectures were also recorded, so sometimes I didn't attend synchronously and watched the recordings.
Offered optional problem solving seminars on Tuesdays.
No other
Psets, rewatching the recorded lectures, and discussions with friends, classmates, and the teacher were other modes of learning I employed.
Office hours!!
Supplemental videos
The modes of learning for this course were mostly live virtual lectures with some recorded lectures.
N/A

virtual office hours
recorded lectures/supplements
problem sets
There were a few recorded lectures, but most of the time it is live.
Lectures were recorded for convenience with screen captures of class notes
I mostly watched the recorded versions of lectures due to timezone issues.
Lectures were also recorded.
In addition to live virtual lectures, the class extensively used breakout rooms, created a robust system of office hours, and encouraged a collaborative problem set environment.
None really, besides some breakout rooms.
Most lectures were synchronous and recorded, but there were days where lectures were asynchronous, in which he just posted a recording and we watched it for next class.
Live virtual lectures with a couple asynchronous recorded lectures thrown in
No other forms.
Recorded videos of live lectures, supplementary recorded videos
The lectures were live and virtual, but I mostly watched them recorded.
Lectures were recorded and synchronous attendance was not mandated.
The live virtual lectures were also recorded.
N/A
Recorded lectures are available for asynchronous students.
The lectures were also recorded and posted to Canvas.
virtual office hours via GatherTown
Class also included office hours and collaborative work sessions.

office hours
n/a
